Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi.

I have not read Mat Bucklands book, however I had an similar issue aft=
er 
messing with paramaters too much. Here is how I've solved it, but YMMV.=


What happened was that very early on almost all connections got disabled =

and run refused to progress anyhwere further (with NN that does nothing, 
=
your error is still around 0.5). What helped was setting disable/toggle 
co=
nnection mutation rate (or whatever equivalent you have in your 
implementa=
tion) to a low value and bumping add node/connection mutation 
rate.

It al=
so helped if I let NN ran trough maybe 3-5 iterations of input 
before look=
ing at output node.

XOR IMO should be solved 100% of time even on most sim=
plest of NEAT 
implementations, so if it's not there may be some bug lurkin=
g in your 
implementation or your paramaters are badly set.

On 05/07/17 03=
:10, q62oorjfziozmti7lxpj37qzx2i57a44c6mrg7hv@... 
[neat] wrote:
>
> =
Hello!
> I've been making a NEAT iimplementation in Scala based on Mat 
> B=
ucklands version described in his book "ai techniques for game 
> programmi=
ng". Now my code works and all (or at least it kinda works), 
> however whe=
n I try to solve the simple XoR problem the implementation 
> only manages =
to solve it about 35% of the time.
>
>
> I would of course want this to bec=
ome a little higher, so I'm 
> wondering if anyone else have experienced si=
milar issues, and if so 
> what did you do to solve it. I've tried to chang=
e the parameters 
> around, but so far without any major changes.
>
> I als=
o wonder how good Mat bucklands version is compared to the other 
> sources=
 of NEAT. Is it just as good, or does the simplicity (I found 
> easier to =
understand than other NEAT implementations) come with a price?
>
>
> 


--------------1EF3AE7FEC70F1DDC501BF11
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

=
    Hi.<br>
    <br>
    I have not read Mat Bucklands book, however I had =
an similar issue
    after messing with paramaters too much. Here is how I'=
ve solved it,
    but YMMV.<br>
    <br>
    What happened was that very ea=
rly on almost all connections got
    disabled and run refused to progress =
anyhwere further (with NN that
    does nothing, your error is still around=
 0.5). What helped was
    setting disable/toggle connection mutation rate =
(or whatever
    equivalent you have in your implementation) to a low value=
 and
    bumping add node/connection mutation rate.<br>
    <br>
    It als=
o helped if I let NN ran trough maybe 3-5 iterations of input
    before lo=
oking at output node.<br>
    <br>
    XOR IMO should be solved 100% of tim=
e even on most simplest of NEAT
    implementations, so if it's not there m=
ay be some bug lurking in
    your implementation or your paramaters are ba=
dly set.<br>

p><span>Hello!<br>
                I've been making a NEAT iimplementation =
in Scala based
                on Mat Bucklands version described in his bo=
ok "ai
                techniques for game programming". Now my code works =
and
                all (or at least it kinda works), however when I try to=

                solve the simple XoR problem the implementation only
     =
           manages to solve it about 35% of the time.</span></p>
          =
  <p><span><br>
              </span></p>
            <p><span>I would of c=
ourse want this to become a little
                higher, so I'm wondering=
 if anyone else have experienced
                similar issues, and if so =
what did you do to solve it.
                I've tried to change the param=
eters around, but so far
                without any major changes.<br>
   =
             <br>
                I also wonder how good Mat bucklands vers=
ion is compared
                to the other sources of NEAT. Is it just as=
 good, or
                does the simplicity (I found easier to understand=
 than
                other NEAT implementations) come with a price?<br>
  =
              <br>
                <br>
              </span></p>
